fields.description: Merge from master branch to dev branch not showing changed files in unstaged files.  The commit message was populated with the correct changed files, but yet we cannot see the files in the staged/unstaged pane.  Conflicted files were correctly listed in the commit message.  The merge does appear to have worked but the history does not show any files.
fields.summary: Merge from master branch to dev branch not showing changed files in unstaged files

fields.description:
If i provide more than one Jira Issues in a commit message, some issues are not higlighted correctly. (But Stash does it correct)

e.g. If i provide {{ABC-123, ABC-124}} in a commit msg, ABC-123 will not be recognized as a ticket number, but ABC-124 will be. Stash is able to recognize both numbers a Jiri Tickets.
fields.summary: Comma separated issues not highlighted correctly

fields.description:
Steps:

- given an unstaged (or staged) file with a long path name, e.g. "project/src/main/java/com/example/xxxxxxxxx/Class.java"
- go to the File status view
- enlarge the diff area by dragging the double arrow icon to the left
- actual: the name of the unstaged file is not visible anymore; you will read something like "project/src/mai ..." !01.png|thumbnail!
- expected: the displayed path should be something like : "proj ... Class.java"
- refresh the view, e.g. by pressing F5 or by changing to "Log / history" and then back to "File status"
- now the user will read "proj ... Class.java" as expected !02.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: File status view: resizing the diff area: file names are not visible

fields.description:
When using Git, we often create patches with the 'git diff' command. SourceTree allows to view the content of stashes but fail to explore diff files (they are just seen as plain text files).
However, git diff is better than git stash because stash should only be used temporarly to quickly switch to another branch, check/fix something, and get back to the first branch and 'stash pop' to continue the current dev.
fields.summary: View the content of diff files (not as plain text but with colors, etc)

fields.description:
I was performing a commit on a local branch and ST crashed.  It appears the commit was successful - the crash occurred after that.

Please see the attached crash log.
fields.summary: Crash during git commit

fields.description:
After using SourceTree for a while, I can't open the merge tool by context menu 'Resolve Conflicts' -> 'Launch External Merge Tool'

I think there maybe a problem while SourceTree tried to send command line argument to git (please see [^2015-11-02_14-41-36.png])

My setting:
- Uses system git: git version 2.6.1.windows.1
- Integrate with: Beyond Compare 4
fields.summary: Cannot launch external merge tool (Beyond Compare,...)

fields.description: After updating system git from 1.9.5 to 2.6.2 SourceTree can't push to the repo when using SSH but works just fine when using HTTPS. SSH works fine if push using the terminal.
fields.summary: can not push through ssh with newest git for windows
Source Tree Crashed without any error explanation

fields.description:
The following describes the bug:

Select "Fluid staging" mode in the File Status page and click "Stage hunk" button. Then, you will find the mode suddenly changes to "Splid view staging".

Looking forward to your updates on this issue. Thanks!
fields.summary: “Fluid staging” automatically changed to “Splid view staging”

fields.description: Integration into SourceTree of Bitbucket repository Issues.  To be able to view and manage Issues for a repo from within SourceTree.
fields.summary: Integrate with Bitbucket Issues

fields.description:
I have created a file in my IDE, staged it right after creation, then changed its case using IDE or Windows Explorer.

In Source Tree, the ready-to-stage changes don't include case change. See screenshot. 

If I stage changes, the file case is incorrect.

In my case, since it's Java code, we have build failure in integration system because file name and Java class name do not match as per case.

The workaround is to unstage file at all, then the correct case is displayed (see second small screenshot).

!2015-10-30_10-59-18.png|thumbnail!

!2015-10-30_11-06-03.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: File case change on disk has no effect on already staged file

fields.description:
This is the same ticket as SRCTREE-3243 but I made it since its the same suggestion but on different platforms.

I have noticed as I am trying to "sell" using atlassian to my company (which has a lot of older developers) they can't see from sourcetree which branch is checked out.

Currently it is merely bolded, but it would be nice to be able to change it so its more noticeable such as put a simple icon next to it or change the background color or something to make it more obvious.
fields.summary: Make checked out branch more noticeable

fields.description:
A merge commit has two parents. (Or more, if it's an octopus merge.) 
SourceTree only shows the diff to one of the parents, but seeing the diff to the second parent is useful.
fields.summary: Ability for SourceTree to show diff to the second parent in merge commits

fields.description: Hi I am  unable to clone my project from bit bucket it continues on showing downloading screen.
fields.summary: Unable to clone from bitbucket

fields.description: Implement a new functionality, where can be possible to do a Diff of two Microsoft  Word (Doc, Docx) files.
fields.summary: Diff for Microsoft Word (doc, docx) files.
SourceTree crashes when Creating Pull Request

fields.description:
*Repro*
- Merge some branch into the current branch.
- May some files conflicting
- Use some mergetool to get rid of the merge conflicts
=> There is no commit message prepared.

*Expected*
There is a commit message prepared and I can commit immediately.

I had a look at the .git folder. Git correctly generates the MERGE_MSG file which usually be used by SourceTree in older versions but not in 1.6.22
fields.summary: MERGE_MSG is not used by SourceTree

fields.description: It would be nice to add an option to change the date format. Actually the 12h is forced, and I'm definitely not used to it. A 24h format would be great !
fields.summary: Possibility to change the date format

fields.description: I launched the software and got the following crash.
fields.summary: Crash on launch

fields.description: SourceTree can't find updates (new commits) of projects. I have to delete and reclone the repositorys to get new commits WHICH IS TOTALLY ANNOYING
fields.summary: Can not find updates

fields.summary: Crash on starting git flow

fields.description:
See screenshot.

For example; when you push or pull and immediately after that switch to another branch or try to create a new feature/hotfix (git flow) -  an error of ".git/index.lock" file is thrown.

This happens often!

This lock file doesn't exists but SourceTree thinks it's still locked. 

Once the error is thrown, it stays until you restart SourceTree.

Issue fixed when using embedded Git.
fields.summary: Git 2.6.2 causing .git/index.lock errors during any operation or action.

fields.description: I have some bookmarks and repositories in source and they seem to persist after I close the app. However if I add any new bookmarks and repositories, close source then reopen it, those new items are no longer in the tree.
fields.summary: bookmarks and repositories not saved in tree after closing sourcetree

fields.description:
After performing a Ctrl+Shift+M in SourceTree to trigger a merge, it's best if users are allowed to use the arrow buttons to select the commit instead of needing to use a mouse to achieve it. 

This will help save time and being able to use the feature efficiently.
fields.summary: Improvement Request: After performing a Ctrl+Shift+M in SourceTree to trigger a merge, it's best if users are allowed to use the arrow buttons to select the commit to merge.

fields.description:
The "Push changes immediately to" checkbox on the commit window can be toggled by clicking anywhere to the left of the "Commit" button. This includes the substantial blank area between the label text for the checkbox and the "Commit" button. This makes it very easy to accidentally toggle the checkbox.

I have already pushed twice when only intending to commit as a result of this.
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately to" clickable region extends beyond text label

fields.description: When working with files other than source code it would be incredibly useful if external tools could be set up to perform the merging currently performed internally in SourceTree. It will help to set up an external merge tool to help resolve conflicts once they have been identified, but for certain types of data the internal merge logic misses conflicts in the data that are significant or produces ill-formed data where a custom merge tool would cope.
fields.summary: Add ability to override internal merge tool

fields.description:
A good feature would be to be able to click a button 'Pull All' or something like that, and do a git pull on every repo.

This feature is particular useful when working with 5-6 repos every day
fields.summary: Pulling from all repositories

fields.description:
Some files have slash as a path separator and some have backslash...
This also sometimes causes improper working of {{.gitignore}}
fields.summary: Random / and \ combination

fields.description:
A different user used SourceTree for Mac to push a new file with the name "Math G3 OP v2-2015Oct19-10:47:52.00.RData".  This was successful.

When I try to pull this file using SourceTree for Windows, I get an error because ":" is not allowed to appear in file names on Windows, though it's legal on Mac and apparently in Git.  I get the following error message:

Updating ecaa80d..0f0166a
error: unable to create file Math G3 OP v2-2015Oct19-10:47:52.00.RData (Invalid argument)
Completed with errors, see above.

When I click through the error and cancel the pull, my Working Copy shows all other files from the failed pull in my local "Unstaged Files" list.  So now I have to remove/discard all their changes to clean my working copy before I can make any new commits.
fields.summary: Pull fails when filenames contain illegal characters

fields.description:
Sourcetree UI crashes on Windows 10 running on Virtualbox if the 'Enable 3D Acceleration' option is enabled.

It shows up in windows task manager then silently crashes.

Workaround: Disable 'Enable 3D Acceleration' option if running Sourcetree on Windows 10 on Virtualbox
fields.summary: Sourcetree UI crashes on Windows 10 running on Virtualbox if the 'Enable 3D Acceleration' option is enabled

fields.description:
Problem description is here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/29952634/answers/31674083

The key passphrase prompt is not visible to enter it.

Workaround - create a new SSH key without a passphrase and that works fine.
fields.summary: Unable to connect with SSH

fields.description:
Cloning a repository containing a submodule the .gitmodules contains a reference to the submodule URL, as well as a branch that I assume is used to track progress in the origin of the submodule repository.

As it stands today, the only time I know I can see/affect the tracked branch name is while creating the submodule link. I can change the source URL, but I have no options of changing which branch is being tracked...

When opening the submodule repository within Sourcetree and actively switch to a branch I would suggest that the submodule reference (in .gitmodules) should update the metadata about which branch it should be checking for new commits.

As our current submodules points out commits that are not part of the branch we point it at we have quite a few cases where some issues occur:
a) We don't get any indication if there are newer commits on the same branch.
b) We get a detached head with no knowledge what branch we would like to commit/branch from if/when we want to work with the actual submodule in its place.
c) We sometime even loose track of the actual commit pointed at and get no tagged HEAD...
fields.summary: Submodule does not track branch/commit

fields.description:
Created two branches, and added two bookmarks onto branch "one", added changes to the different bookmarks which results in two heads. On the "branches" list it's showing two instances of "one" without much clarification, it would be nicer to, in order of preference (1 = best, 4 = worst):

# on each mention of "one", in parentheses, the name of the bookmark
# on each mention of "one", in parentheses, the revision number/hash of that head
# on each mention of "one", in parentheses, "head 1", "head 2" and so on.
# have only 1 "one" branch showing under branches

See image showing:

Branches:
* default
* one
* one
* two

{code:bash}
F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg log --graph
@  changeset:   0:99c713dcdb11
   tag:         tip
   user:        redacted
   date:        Tue Oct 20 11:40:53 2015 +0100
   summary:     Test

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg branch one
marked working directory as branch one
(branches are permanent and global, did you want a bookmark?)

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Create branch one"

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg branch two
marked working directory as branch two
(branches are permanent and global, did you want a bookmark?)

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg update -r 0
0 files updated, 0 files merged, 0 files removed, 0 files unresolved

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg branch two
marked working directory as branch two
(branches are permanent and global, did you want a bookmark?)

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Create branch two"

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg log --graph
@  changeset:   2:dcbebb1671d3
|  branch:      two
|  tag:         tip
|  parent:      0:99c713dcdb11
|  user:        redacted
|  date:        Tue Oct 20 11:51:51 2015 +0100
|  summary:     Create branch two
|
| o  changeset:   1:3536b15da43c
|/   branch:      one
|    user:        redacted
|    date:        Tue Oct 20 11:51:04 2015 +0100
|    summary:     Create branch one
|
o  changeset:   0:99c713dcdb11
   user:        redacted
   date:        Tue Oct 20 11:40:53 2015 +0100
   summary:     Test


F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg branch
two

#Update file here and add some random junk to it

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Add test two"

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg update -r one
1 files updated, 0 files merged, 0 files removed, 0 files unresolved

#Update file here to add some other random junk to it

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Add test one"

# create two bookmarks on one

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg bookmark one/foo

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg bookmark one/bar

#Update file here to add some other random junk to it

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg status
M file

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg bookmark
 * one/bar                   4:b508704944cc
   one/foo                   4:b508704944cc

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Add onebar"

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg update one/foo
1 files updated, 0 files merged, 0 files removed, 0 files unresolved
(activating bookmark one/foo)

#Update file here to add some other random junk to it

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg commit -m "Add onefoo"
created new head

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg update -r two
1 files updated, 0 files merged, 0 files removed, 0 files unresolved
(leaving bookmark one/foo)

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg update -r one
1 files updated, 0 files merged, 0 files removed, 0 files unresolved

F:\WORK\bookmark-testing>hg branches
one                            6:54cc245cf257
two                            3:4e2226dfd315
default                        0:99c713dcdb11 (inactive)
{code}

It'll be really useful for every developer that uses such branching model: http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/
with SourceTree.

fields.description:
There should be an option to turn on a warning when working on a detached head and trying to commit. The warning would say something like "You're committing to a detached head, is that what you really wanted to do?". Ideally the dialog would also give you the option to commit to a branch instead - offering you a list of branches who's position match the current head.

Currently, Sourcetree doesn't warn when trying to commit on a detached head, possibly causing users to lose their work.
fields.summary: Option to warn before committing to a detached head

fields.description:
When doing a fresh install of SourceTree it asks you to "clone your first repo".
In that dialog let's say you have the following repositories in this order:
Pamela
Kelly
Anna
Dana

Ask it to filter by the letters "na" and it will show only:
Anna
Dana

Now select Anna from that filtered list and check at the bottom of the dialog the suggested folder where the cloning is going to take place. In my computer it is suggesting "Pamela" instead of "Anna". If I select Dana then it suggests the name "Kelly" instead of "Dana".
What I think is happening is SourceTree is suggesting for the each item of the filtered list the name of the item at the same position but in the unfiltered list.

This behaviour is pretty consistent, but notice it only happens in the first dialog that appears after a fresh install. This doesn't happen in the normal "Clone" dialog.
fields.summary: Wrong folder suggested
Remove -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false

Will be great a revision mode that enable to review local changes efficiently.

fields.description:
Hello, 

I am trying to create a template commit message in sourcetree, but no success. I have already tried with git config --global commit.template and to use prepare-commit-msg hook and it worked in both cases from the command line, but not in sourcetree. I have made research on internet and it seems that a lot of people have this problem. Is there any other solution or is a missing feature/limitation? 
P.S. I am using SourceTree 1.6.21.0 on Windows 7.

fields.description:
To reproduce.

# Commit a file, containing at least one line of text, to a Mecurial repo.
# add new lines above the existing line.
# view in sourcetree, it should be possible to discard the hunk/lines
# add new lines below the last line.
# view in sourcetee, it will give a patch.exe error when trying to discard the hunk/lines.
fields.summary: Unable to DIscard Hunk/Lines when the changes include the last lines of the file.

fields.description: When using semantic versioning and git-flow you can end up with a very long list of tags. I think it would be useful if these were listed in a "nested format", based on the dots, similar to how tags (and branches) with slashes are presented. This would possibly also make SRCTREEWIN-2267 a moot point.
fields.summary: Show tags with dots in nested format, like those with slashes
Crash on startup

fields.description:
The problem occurs mostly, when I am trying to stage hunks containing non-Latin (in my case German) characters. In editor they are visible as "�".
In SourceTree I receive the following error message:

{noformat}
'git apply' failed with code 1: Checking patch xxx...
error: while searching for:
OVNI_PREFIX = 'ovni_'; // Standardname f�r Videoschnittstellen-DLL
error: patch failed: xxx:148
error: xxx: patch does not apply
{noformat}

This problem seems do not appear while using git commands {{git add -p}} or {{git reset -p}}. I can stage changes using terminal, but attempt to unstage it using SourceTree fails also.

Please follow also [this discussion|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/30950752/comments/31655884].

The screenshot I included in the attachment.
fields.summary: Commit problems with German characters

fields.description:
It would be very helpful to be able to set the "Do not fast-forward when merging, always create commit" option at a branch level.

Our git workflow requires a new commit every time we merge into specific branches.  This is required so our CI workflow kicks off properly.
fields.summary: "Do not fast forward when merging" per branch

Imediately a modal window pops up, with title Ooops!.
Oh dear. We're sorry, SourceTree just crashed. How terribly embarrassing.

With every restart of the application, selecting "Create pull request..", triggers the crash.

fields.description:
After installing/upgrading to Bitbucket server 4.0.2 I am no longer able to Clone in SourceTree.

Steps to Duplicate:
# Launch Sourcetree
# On the Repository Browser click on remote and you will see a list of repositories on the Bitbucket server
# Click clone
# Note that there is a message that says "This is not a valid source path / URL" and the URL looks like: {{http://cdrummond@localhost/stash///git/TEST/test.git}}
# Note that the Source URL has multiple problems:
# # The port is missing.  I connect to Stash on port 7990 and the port is not there
# # The /scm is missing.  In its place is just //
# # There is an invalid /git in the URL
# # The Project is displayed in all uppercase letters

You can also reproduce this by clicking on the Clone in SourceTree button that displays in Bitbucket Server on the repository clone page. In this case the URL is still malformed but it looks different, from the looks of the Source URL (which can not be edited) everything seems correct but you still get the "This is not a valid source path / URL" messager and you can not click the clone button.
fields.summary: Unable to clone from Bitbucket Server 4.0.2

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false clone --recursive https://Jakob97@bitbucket.org/Jakob97/mastermind.git E:\BitBucket\mastermind
Cloning into 'E:\BitBucket\mastermind'...
fatal: cannot copy 'C:\Users\Philipp\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree\git_local\share\git-core\templates/hooks/pre-push.sample' to 'E:/BitBucket/mastermind/.git/hooks/pre-push.sample': Invalid argument

fields.description:
Preconditions: 
- SourceTree has been active for more than one day
- System memory is running low (not sure if this is related with the issue)

Steps to reproduce:

The issue can be resolved by restarting SourceTree

This looks to be a known bug that has not yet been addressed by Atlassian, despite other Jira tickets marking the issue as fixed.

In SourceTree, I keep getting prompted to authenticate my session, despite telling SourceTree to remember my credentials.
fields.summary: SourceTree Keeps Prompting to Authenticate
Rebase feature could allow for keeping Commit dates same as Authored dates.

fields.description:
I would like you to add support for Visual Studio Online to the Hosted Accounts function.
So that it's easier to clone existing repos.

fields.description: Remote branches under Remotes/origin list are not updated when a remote branch is deleted by someone else.
fields.summary: Remote branches under Remotes/origin list are not updated when a remote branch is deleted by someone else

fields.description:
SourceTree fails with the following message when doing anything related with git:

'git _something_' failed with code 128: fatal: unable to access 'H:\/.config/git/config': Invalid argument

My gitconfig is located in the default path: C:\Users\myusername ; however SourceTree tries to access H:, which is a network drive that is not connected at the moment.

Finally, I found that I have the following environment variable:
HOMEDRIVE=H:

It seems that when trying to read the environment variable HOME, it read HOMEDRIVE instead.



I solved this by adding a new environment variable: HOME=C:\Users\myusername

However this is a bug because it should never read HOMEDRIVE.
fields.summary: SourceTree fails to start, open and everything if you have a HOMEDRIVE env variable

fields.description:
Strange today my sourcetree keeps crashing on create pull request. 

versions 1.6.19 to 21
fields.summary: crash on pull request

fields.description: SourceTree fails to connect if stash/bitbucket server requires client certificate.  SourceTree should be able to use client certificate from Windows certificate store, OS-X Keychain application or from file.
fields.summary: Client certificate authentication on https

fields.description: When you set the "File status" window in "Flat list (multiple column)" and "Split View Staging" visualization mode, the visualized path of files in root directory are wrong.
fields.summary: Path error in "Flat list (multiple column)" and "Split View Staging" mode

fields.description:
When I click the Reset to Commit dialog box with the mouse and then press the Tab key, tabbing occurs in SourceTree's main window, not in the dialog box.  That cannot be correct behavour.

Perhaps related, as the 'Using mode' drop-down is the only modifiable field, it should be initially focused to facilitate modification by keyboard.  It is not.

I would like to be able to use the keyboard to change the value of the 'Using mode' drop-down of the Reset to Commit dialog box, especially as, in my case, I have wanted to change the default value 100% of the time I've used the dialog box.

Like all similar SourceTree dialog boxes, this one has to be activated with the mouse before changes can be made.  I'm resigned to the likelihood that this is an architectural limitation that will not be feasible to change.  That is not what I'm asking for.

However, once the dialog box is clicked to activate it, it ought to be possible to navigate to the drop-down using the tab key and then change the value with the up and down arrow keys.  It is the tabbing that is not working.  If I click the drop-down with the mouse, then I can change the value with the up and down arrow keys.

Compare this screenshot  of the Reset to Commit dialog box when initially shown !B1ResetToCommitDialog.png|thumbnail! with this screenshot of the well-behaved Pull dialog box when initially shown  !B2PullDialog.png|thumbnail!.  The difference to notice is that the first drop-down of the Pull dialog has the focus, as shown by the dotted focus rectangle, whereas the Reset to Commit dialog has a false focus rectangle at top edge.  (I do not always see the false focus rectangle and do not know how to replicate it.  But that variation makes no difference to whether tabbing will work on the dialog box.)

Not showable by screenshot is the fact that I can tab to the Pull dialog's second drop-down, as I would expect.
fields.summary: Cannot tab within Reset to Commit dialog box

fields.description:
Occasionally a "changed" file pops up as uncommitted change, showing something like this:
 !Capture.PNG|thumbnail! 

Not a single letter has changed, so this should not be included in uncommitted changes. This will otherwise lead to commits accidentally containing large chunks of new code that isn't new at all, making it difficult to track actual changes.
fields.summary: No changes are still marked as changes

fields.description: I have SourceTree pinned to my task bar as I use it so often. Whenever I upgrade, the actual sourcetree icon vanishes and gets replaced by default (blank). I have to unpin and re-pin to fix the issue which actually puts me off from upgrading.
fields.summary: Pinned icon on the taskbar loses the icon after upgrade

fields.description: We are not that happy with the .gitignore functionality.  We all have different local files we want to ignore.  I don't want to push my .gitignore file, either.  I want to ignore it as well, so it won't try to merge that on the far end.  Can we ignore .gitignore?
fields.summary: Ignore .gitignore

fields.description: Was just using normally. Tried to open a PR through source tree when crash occurred.
fields.summary: Crashed when opening PR

fields.description: Source tree does not show all registered submodules for a git repository. It seems that source tree does not the git .gitmodules file to find the submodules. i suspect that it uses its own meta files which can easily differ from the git data.
fields.summary: Source tree does not show all registered submodules

fields.description:
I would love to get a developer's answer to this, what is the actual state of the project?

Almost a year ago you promised us in a blog post that the silence is finally over, that a new project manager took over and the days of ST for Windows have finally come. Since then actually nothing happened and all we got was some small bugfixes, most of them for bugs introduced 5 minutes before, with the "bug fix" release before.

So far we are still lacking waaaaaay behind the OS X version of ST with missing basic features like force pushing and squashing.

So what is up with that? And please no marketing department answer. If you just don't have the people to work on the Windows version then say so.
fields.summary: State of the Project

fields.description:
Sourcetree is failing to connect to bitbucket with SSH keys, seems like an issue with pageant. After disable of SSH everything is OK.
Same account and configuration is OK in Win7.
fields.summary: Sourcetree failing SSH with Windows 10

fields.description:
Crash on startup since upgrade to 1.6.21, with the error message "Oh dear. We're sorry, but SourceTree just crashed."

I was using 1.6.13 before and this never happened.
I tried to uninstall 1.6.21 and reinstall 1.6.13 but didn't fix the crash.
fields.summary: Crash on startup

fields.description: Either have an option in the options window, or simply remember the state of the push changes immediately flag.  It's slightly annoying to uncheck it every time that I commit since pushing is entirely too slow to do every time I commit.
fields.summary: Remember that I don't want to push every time I commit

fields.description: I have a folder C:\Dev and sub-folders of that are all git repo's.  I have a VS 2015 solution where I may do work on 3 repo's.  Each repo is a tab in SourceTree.  When I close out of VS 2015 and go to SourceTree I expect each bookmark on the left would show me where local changes are that need to be committed yet it doesn't.  I have to know each repo I worked in and then activate that tab and only then will it poll for local changes it seems.  This is prone to a developer missing a commit if they don't realize something got changed in a repo they weren't expecting for example.  We need better remote polling per the frequency set in option for all repo's as well as better local file change detection.
fields.summary: Repo's do not detect local changes

fields.description:
Conflicts when I merge with another branch.
I Right click on target file -> Resolve conflicts -> Resolve using 'Mine' 
and then alert popup to show confirm resolve using their.
But I choose ok it's resolve using mine. It's confusion.
fields.summary: Click using mine but it's show alert popup using their.

fields.description:
When I right-click on my branch and select "Create Pull Request", the application crashes.
This only happens on the project that is integrated with Bitbucket.  I have other projects on GitHub and Stash, and those work fine.
fields.summary: Crash when attempting to create pull request
commit Graph point do not align at the commit line.

fields.description:
Randomly when a user have more than one tab open and a pull is done on one of the tabs, the output process may happen in another repository tab instead.

It tends to happen after the program has been running for a while (1+ hour?).
fields.summary: Git pull output ocassionally appears in the wrong tab.

fields.description:
When working in a repo, SourceTree no longer automatically lists new files in the "Unstaged File" section unless I remember to do an "Add/Remove Files" before every commit. This used to work just fine when I first installed and for several versions, but for the last several versions, it hasn't. Sorry, I don't know when it ceased working but it has been months. Is there a setting I don't have configured correctly? I have ST v. 1.6.21.0 and PuTTY 2012-06-04r9551 if that helps.

I've talked with other developers and they have not encountered this issue.
fields.summary: SourceTree no longer shows new files

fields.description: Sometimes the SourceTree hangs on loading git history and only its restart helps.
fields.summary: Everloading status after F5

fields.description:
Customer provided this via a Support ticket to request to add a button that clean/remove local merged branches

{code}
echo "The following remote branches are fully merged into master and will be removed:" 
git branch --merged | grep -v "\*" | grep -v master | grep -v dev 
read -p "Continue (y/n)?" 
if [ "$REPLY" == "y" ] 
then 
	#echo "ok"
	git branch --merged | grep -v "\*" | grep -v master | grep -v dev | xargs -n 1 git branch -d
	echo "Obsolete branches are removed" 
fi
{code}
fields.summary: Request: Add button to clean/remove local merged branches
